qas.question: Since 1993, which body has had power to enact measures?
This body makes provisions in respect to matters concerning whom?

answers.text: Church of England in the Island

qas.question: Up until 1994, royal assent was given by whom?
Which position now has the power to grant royal assent?
Before what year was royal assent approved by Order in Council?
Who currently holds the power to grant royal assent to measures?
During which years did the Synod have power to enact measures?

plausible_answers.text: the Sodor and Man Diocesan Synod

qas.question: Since 1983, who has had power to enact measures?
Before 1994, royal dissent was granted by whom?
Currently, royal dissent has been delegated to whom?

context: Since 1993, <b7_0>the <a0_0>Sodor and Man Diocesan Synod<b7_0/><a0_0/> has had power to enact measures making provision "with respect to any matter concerning the <a1_0>Church of England in the Island<a1_0/>". If approved by Tynwald, a measure "shall have the force and effect of an Act of Tynwald upon the Royal Assent thereto being announced to Tynwald". <a6_0>Between 1979 and 1993<a6_0/>, the Synod had similar powers, but limited to the extension to the Isle of Man of measures of the General Synod. Before <a4_0>1994<a4_0/>, royal assent was granted by <a2_0><b8_0>Order in Council<b8_0/><a2_0/>, as for a bill, but the power to grant royal assent to measures has now been delegated to <a5_0>the <a3_0><b9_0>lieutenant governor<b9_0/><a5_0/><a3_0/>. <b10_0>A Measure<b10_0/> does not require promulgation.
